triplet_2157_question.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2157_question.text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?
triplet_2157_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

triplet_2157_rating.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2157_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: Many express frustration with “tipping culture,” saying it has expanded beyond traditional contexts and often feels coercive, especially with point-of-sale screens that default to high tip prompts.

  • Pay and policy: The most common reform called for is shifting to livable, fair base wages so workers don’t have to rely on tips. Several suggest raising menu prices or adding a built-in service charge to replace discretionary tipping. Some propose guaranteeing at least the standard minimum wage for tipped workers, with a few advocating a specific service charge (e.g., 10%).

  • Scope and expectations: Many want tipping to be optional, tied to quality of service, and limited to situations involving meaningful service (e.g., sit-down restaurants), not for pickup, drive-thru, or minimal interaction.

  • Timing and UI: Multiple comments call for tips to be requested only after service is delivered, with clearer “no tip” options and less intrusive prompts.

  • Pro-tipping perspectives: A noticeable minority strongly support tipping as an incentive for excellent service, with some favoring mandatory tipping or higher, standardized tip amounts. A few suggest benefits for tipping (thank-you notes, coupons) and tax relief on tips.

  • Competing values: There is broad empathy for underpaid service workers alongside consumer fatigue with pressure to tip everywhere. Many say they will continue tipping under the current system while urging systemic changes that make tips a true bonus rather than a necessity.

triplet_2157_comparison.question: What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_2157_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: Many express frustration with “tipping culture,” saying it has expanded beyond traditional contexts and often feels coercive, especially with point-of-sale screens that default to high tip prompts.

  • Pay and policy: The most common reform called for is shifting to livable, fair base wages so workers don’t have to rely on tips. Several suggest raising menu prices or adding a built-in service charge to replace discretionary tipping. Some propose guaranteeing at least the standard minimum wage for tipped workers, with a few advocating a specific service charge (e.g., 10%).

  • Scope and expectations: Many want tipping to be optional, tied to quality of service, and limited to situations involving meaningful service (e.g., sit-down restaurants), not for pickup, drive-thru, or minimal interaction.

  • Timing and UI: Multiple comments call for tips to be requested only after service is delivered, with clearer “no tip” options and less intrusive prompts.

  • Pro-tipping perspectives: A noticeable minority strongly support tipping as an incentive for excellent service, with some favoring mandatory tipping or higher, standardized tip amounts. A few suggest benefits for tipping (thank-you notes, coupons) and tax relief on tips.

  • Competing values: There is broad empathy for underpaid service workers alongside consumer fatigue with pressure to tip everywhere. Many say they will continue tipping under the current system while urging systemic changes that make tips a true bonus rather than a necessity.

Summary B

Based on the comments provided, here is an overall summary of the perspectives on tipping:

A significant number of commenters express frustration with the current state of tipping culture, describing it as "out of control," "overkill," and "over-expected." A major point of contention is the expansion of tip requests to transactions with minimal or no direct service, such as at coffee shops or for takeout orders. Many feel pressured or "bullied" into tipping by modern point-of-sale tablets that often default to a tip screen, making it uncomfortable to decline.

The most prevalent theme is that the tipping system allows employers to underpay their staff, shifting the responsibility of providing a livable wage from the business to the consumer. Consequently, the most frequently proposed solution is to eliminate the current tipping system entirely. In its place, many advocate for businesses to be required to pay their employees a fair, livable wage, even if that means higher prices for goods and services.

While the desire to abolish the system is strong, many still believe in tipping as a voluntary reward for exceptional service. The core principle for this group is that tips should be earned based on the quality of service provided, not be an obligation or an expectation for every transaction.

Other suggestions for reform include replacing tipping with a mandatory service charge, changing the standard from percentages to fixed amounts, and making the "no tip" option on payment systems more accessible. Overall, while some see tipping as a beneficial way to show appreciation, the prevailing sentiment is that the system is fundamentally flawed, creating pressure on customers and failing to provide stable, fair compensation for workers.
